prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for replying to my sister when she messaged me "Happy Birthday" when me (34m) and my gf (33f) were out to eat?
She doesn't like when I use my phone when we are out.  Afterwards she wouldn't talk to me the rest of the night.  I'm still pissed off, I can never catch a break.  I also had to pay for dinner, I assumed she was paying.  I should also add, before we went out she asked something along the lines of "do you want to go out for a birthday dinner?" I wouldn't have went if I knew I was paying because I just emptied my savings and checking to pay off a loan.
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So the situation is that the person replied to their sister's birthday message while they were out to eat with their girlfriend. The girlfriend doesn't like when he uses his phone during meals. After replying, she wouldn't talk to him the rest of the night. Then he's also upset because he had to pay for dinner, thinking she was going to, and he had just spent his savings to pay off a loan.

First, I need to break down the key points. The main issue seems to be the phone use. The girlfriend asked him not to use the phone when they're out, and he did. That probably hurt her feelings, leading her to be silent the rest of the night. Then there's the financial aspect—paying for dinner when he expected her to, but he didn't mention the loan situation before the dinner. 

So, was replying to the sister's message disrespectful? If the girlfriend has a rule against phone use during meals, then ignoring that could be seen as dismissive. Even if it was just a birthday message, the act of using the phone might have been seen as a breach of trust or respect, depending on their agreement. 

Then, the financial part. He didn't mention he was broke after paying off a loan before agreeing to dinner. That's on him. If he expected her to pay, but he didn't communicate his financial situation, he might have assumed she would cover it. However, assuming someone will pay without discussing it can lead to misunderstandings. 

Putting it all together: He broke a boundary by using his phone, which upset her. He also didn't communicate his financial situation, leading to an unexpected expense. Both issues could contribute to her being upset. So, he might be at fault for both actions. However, maybe the sister's message was just a quick reply, but given the girlfriend's established preference, he should have prioritized her feelings. 

I think the main point is the phone use. If he had known she wouldn't talk to him after, maybe he should have handled it differently. Also, the financial part is his responsibility for not communicating his situation. So, he's in the wrong for both aspects. Answer A.
